title: C04-1128

sentences.text: While sentence extraction as an approach to summarization has been shown to work in documents of certain genres , because of the conversational nature of email communication where utterances are made in relation to one made previously , sentence extraction may not capture the necessary segments of dialogue that would make a summary coherent .
In this paper , we present our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization .
We show that various features based on the structure of email-threads can be used to improve upon lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing .

summary: While sentence extraction as an approach to summarization has been shown to work in documents of certain genres , because of the conversational nature of email communication where utterances are made in relation to one made previously , sentence extraction may not capture the necessary segments of dialogue that would make a summary coherent . In this paper , we present our work on the detection of question-answer pairs in an email conversation for the task of email summarization . We show that various features based on the structure of email-threads can be used to improve upon lexical similarity of discourse segments for question-answer pairing .
kg2text: This paper presents research on the detection of question-answer pairs, which is essential for the task of email summarization. The detection of question-answer pairs has a broader term known as question-answer pairing. To enhance the effectiveness of question-answer pairing, various features based on the structure of email-threads can be utilized. These features, which also encompass the broader category of email-threads, can improve upon the identification of lexical similarity of discourse segments and discourse segments themselves. However, it is important to note that sentence extraction may not capture all segments of dialogue, which are critical for maintaining coherence in email summarization. The task of email summarization is related to the broader concept of summarization, which also includes the use of sentence extraction techniques that have been shown to work effectively in documents of certain genres. Overall, the integration of these elements aims to enhance the process of email summarization by focusing on the relationships between questions and answers within email communications.

The concept of 'lexical similarity of discourse segments' is a specific instance of the broader term 'lexical similarity', which measures the degree of similarity in word choice and phrasing. Similarly, 'documents of certain genres' fall under the general category of 'documents', which encompasses various types of written texts. In the realm of communication, an 'email conversation' is a subset of 'dialogue', highlighting the interactive nature of exchanges in this format. Within these email conversations, 'question-answer pairs' are commonly detected, illustrating structured interactions between participants. Furthermore, 'email communication' is defined by its 'conversational nature', which emphasizes the back-and-forth exchanges typical of dialogue. This conversational aspect is crucial for creating a 'summary' that is 'coherent', ensuring that the main points of the dialogue are logically connected and easily understandable.
